name: Arizona
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Arizona's NIL Law allows a student athlete to earn compensation from the use of their name, image, or likeness, including from a postsecondary education institution as long as the institution does not make payment from money collected from student fees. Institutions may also work with and pay third-party marketing entities to facilitate NIL opportunities for student athletes.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
However, a student athlete may not enter into a contract that compensates him or her for NIL if:
that contract violates intellectual property rights;
the activity conflicts with the student athlete's team's contract; or
the student athlete has not disclosed the proposed contract to their institution.
Limitations on Institution NIL Conduct
An institution may not determine a student athlete's rostering or athletic participation based on their NIL activities. Institutions may also not deny or revoke a student athlete's scholarship or deem them ineligible based on their NIL activity and compensation.
Institutions may not classify a student athlete as an employee of the school based solely on their athletic participation.
Limitations on Athletic Association Conduct
Athletic associations and other regulators may not prevent student athletes or institutions from participating in intercollegiate athletics because of their involvement in NIL activity and compensation.
Violations and Enforcement
Student athletes may seek injunctive relief against an institution or athletic association for a violation of the Arizona NIL law. Institutions may do the same against an athletic association or student athlete. If an institution determines a student athlete has violated the Arizona NIL law, it must notify the student athlete in writing of the determination, after which the student athlete has ten (10) days to correct the violation before the institution can seek injunctive relief.

name: Arkansas
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Arkansas' NIL Law allows a student athlete to enter into a contract and receive compensation for the commercial use of the student athlete’s publicity rights.  As of the April 11, 2023 amendments, student-athletes may now be compensated for NIL use prior to enrollment at an institution.
Institutions of higher education, and their supporting foundations, may create, facilitate, or enable opportunities for student-athletes to earn compensation for use of their NIL.  Although, Institutions are not required to create or facilitate these opportunities, nor are institutions required to compensate student-athletes for the institution’s use of the athlete’s publicity rights.
Organizations qualified as a 501(c)(3) may compensate student-athletes for use of their NIL.
Protections for Student-Athletes Engaged in NIL
Institutions may not maintain any rule or standard that prevents a student-athlete from earning compensation for use of their NIL. This includes prohibition on altering student-athlete’s scholarship eligibility based on receipt of NIL compensation.
Athletic associations or conferences may not (a) prevent an athlete from receiving compensation for NIL, (b) penalize the student for receiving such compensation, or (c) prevent an institution from participating in athletics based on an athlete’s receipt of NIL compensation.
A student-athlete may only rescind an NIL contract, without breach of contract penalty, to the extent they are no longer eligible to participate in any varsity intercollegiate program at an institution of higher education. This provision is far less permissive than its prior iteration, which provided students more opportunities to rescind.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
Student-athletes may not enter into an NIL contract that would:
Require them to endorse or promote any product, logo, or business during a practice, competition, or other varsity intercollegiate activity;
Conflict with the policies of the student-athlete’s institution of commitment or enrollment; or
Involve the student-athlete’s performance (or lack thereof) in an athletic competition.
This law does not authorize the student-athlete to use the name, trademarks, or other intellectual property of the institution at which they are enrolled.
Student Athletes Not Employees
The act specifies that it does not render student-athletes employees of the institution based on their participation in varsity intercollegiate athletic competition. 
No Inducement Provision
No person or entity may offer or give compensation to a student-athlete enrolled at an Arkansas institution for the purpose of inducing them to transfer for another institution of higher education. The Act creates a cause of action for institutions and third-party licensees for violations of this provision.
Declaration of Emergency
As part of its new NIL law, Arkansas declared an emergency. In particular, the General Assembly found this Act immediately necessary because recruits for intercollegiate athletics need to know, as soon as practicable, what the NIL rules are, so that they can properly evaluated athletic programs against one another. In so doing, Arkansas referenced the fact that other states are similarly revising their state’s NIL legislation in an attempt to recruit players.
Additional Provisions
Arkansas’ NIL law was further amended on April 13, 2023 to prohibit state-funded medical schools from using or offering available funds from state tax revenue for name, image, and likeness payments to students-athletes.

name: California
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
California's NIL law allows current and prospective student athletes to earn compensation as a result of the use of the student's name, image, likeness, or athletic reputation.
NIL Agents/Advisors/Representatives
Professional representatives of student athletes must be licensed in California.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
Student athlete contracts for NIL compensation may not conflict with any provision of the athlete's team contract.
Student athletes must disclose the existence of their NIL contracts to their college or university.

name: Colorado
statusDetail: Enacted (3/20/2020); Effective (Originally 1/1/2023, moved up to 7/1/2021); First amendment (06/06/2023); Second amendment (03/28/2025)
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Colorado's NIL law allows student athletes to earn compensation for their name, image, and likeness.
The June 6, 2023 amendment permits institutions to identify, create, solicit, facilitate, and enable NIL opportunities for student-athletes, so long as the institution receives the athlete’s permission. If the institution solicits an NIL opportunity for the student-athlete, they must inform the student-athlete within 72 hours.
The March 28, 2025 amendment permits institutions to directly compensate student-athletes for their name, image, and likeness.
Charitable organizations that are exempt as a 501(c)(3) may also compensate a student-athlete for use of the NIL.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
Student athlete contracts for NIL compensation may not conflict with any provision of the student athlete's team contract.
Student athletes must disclose the existence of their NIL contracts to their athletic director within 72 hours after entering into the contract, or before the next scheduled athletic event that the student athlete participates in, whichever occurs first.
Any person providing legal representation to the student athlete must be a licensed attorney.
Institutional Responsibilities and Limitations
Starting January 15, 2026, institutions each year must submit to the Colorado Department of Higher Education a copy of the annual report they must submit to the NCAA consistent with the NCAA’s reporting requirements that includes data on gender- and sport-based spending, which the Department of Higher Education will publish on its website.
 Institutions may not prevent student-athletes from obtaining professional or legal representation in relation to NIL contract or legal matters.

name: Connecticut
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Connecticut's NIL law allows student athletes to:
earn compensation through an endorsement contract or employment in an activity that is unrelated to his or her college's athletic program; and
obtain the legal or professional representation of an attorney or sports agent through a written agreement.
However, the student athlete must comply with his or her college's policies regarding student athlete endorsement contracts and employment activities.
Required NIL Policies (for Educational Institutions)
Connecticut colleges must adopt one or more policies regarding student athlete endorsement contracts and employment activities, which must include provisions:
requiring a student athlete to disclose and submit a copy of each endorsement contract, written agreement for employment or representation agreement;
prohibiting a student athlete from entering into an agreement that conflicts with the provisions of any agreement to which the college is a party;
prohibiting a student athlete from using or consenting to the use of any institutional marks;
prohibiting a student athlete's from interfering with any official team activities or academic obligations; and
identifying any prohibited endorsements.

name: Delaware
statusDetail:
None.
Delaware does not have a traditional NIL law like other states. Instead, Delaware passed a law that governs the acts of agents of student athletes at Delaware institutions. (See https://legis.delaware.gov/BillDetail/109500).
summary: N/A.

name: District of Columbia
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
DC's NIL law allows student athletes to earn compensation for the name, image, and likeness, but cannot include any name, trademark, service mark, logo, uniform design, or other identifier in their NIL activity.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
An athlete cannot enter into a NIL contract or receive compensation if it is contingent upon:
illegal activity;
the promotion of alcohol, tobacco, other controlled substances, steroids, sports betting and gambling, firearms, or adult entertainment.
An athlete must disclose their NIL contract or agreement to their college or university if the compensation is for $300 or more or if the aggregate amount in a calendar year is $2,000 or more. The college or university must designate an individual or office to receive this information.
Required NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
A college or university must:
educate athletes about NIL agreements and compensations;
provide financial literacy and life skills programming, which must include:
(1) information concerning student loan, financial aid, and debt management;
(2) time management skills and an overview of available academic support services;
(3) budgeting based on cost of attendance, living expenses, and scholarship resources;
(4) an explanation of services offered by and guidance for accessing banks and basic banking products;
(5) an introduction to income taxes, including income earned as an independent contractor; and
(6) warnings about payday and predatory lending practices.
Emergency Declared
On May 6, 2025, the Council of the District of Columbia declared an emergency with respect to the need to amend section 215 of the Uniform College Athlete Name, Image, or Likeness Act of 2022. The resolution calls for two principal amendments:
Permit institutions to assist student athletes in activities related to monetizing their NIL, including selecting an NIL agent; and
Removing the existing prohibition on institutions or conferences directly compensating student athletes for use of their NIL.
The resolution cites to the pending House settlement, indicating emergency amendment of Section 215 is necessary to bring D.C. law in alignment with anticipated NCAA policy and ensure D.C.-based institutions are not left competitively disadvantaged.

name: Florida
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Florida's NIL law allows student athletes to earn compensation for the use of their name, image, and likeness.
Required NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
A college or university must conduct at least two financial literacy, life skills, and entrepreneurship workshops for a minimum of five hours before the graduation of an intercollegiate athlete and must include information concerning:
entrepreneurship;
financial aid;
debt management;
a recommended budget for full and partial grant-in-aid athletes based on the current academic year’s cost attendance;
time management skills necessary for success as an athlete; and
available academic resources.
The workshop may not include any:
marketing, advertising, referral, or solicitation by providers of financial products or services.
Limitation of Liability (for Educational Institutions)
A college, university, or its employees are not liable for any damages to a student-athlete's ability to earn compensation for the use of his or her NIL resulting from decisions and actions routinely taken in the course of intercollegiate athletics.

name: Georgia
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Georgia's NIL law allows student athletes to earn compensation for the use of their name, image or likeness, so long as it is commensurate with the market value of the authorized use of the student athlete's name, image or likeness.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
The student athlete's NIL contract cannot conflict with the student athlete's team contract. The student athlete must disclose their NIL contract to an official of their college or university.
Required NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
Colleges and universities must conduct a financial literacy and life skills workshop for a minimum of five hours at the beginning of the student athlete's first and third academic years, and must include information concerning:
financial aid;
debt management; and
a recommended budget;
time management skills; and
available academic resources.
The workshop cannot include any marketing, advertising, referral or solicitation by providers of financial products or services.
NIL Agents/Advisors/Representatives
Agents representing student athletes must comply with the Federal Sports Agent Responsibility and Trust Act.
Executive Order of Governor (9/17/2024)
On September 17, 2024, Georgia Governor Brian Kemp signed an Executive Order prohibiting the NCAA (or any other organization with authority over collegiate athletics) from enforcing rules against NIL payments made directly by institutions to student athletes. Put another way, the Executive Order permits direct-to-athlete NIL payments by institutions within the State of Georgia. It specifies, however, that funds allocated to institutions by the State of Georgia may not be paid to student-athletes as NIL compensation.
The Executive Order is set to sunset on either (a) the effective date of any federal law governing student-athletes' rights to NIL compensation or (b) the effective date of any settlement in the House litigation (No. 4:20-cv-03919-CW, N.D. Cal.), whichever is earlier.

name: Illinois
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Illinois' NIL law allows student athletes to earn compensation commensurate with market value for the use of the student athlete's name, image, likeness or voice.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
The student athlete cannot receive compensation for the use of their name, image, likeness or voice if it also uses any registered or licensed marks, logos, verbiage, name or designs of a college or university, unless the college or university gives the student-athlete written permission to do so.
The student athlete must disclose their NIL agreement to their college or university. NIL contracts for compensation equal or above $500 must be in writing and provided to the college or university prior to execution of the agreement or prior to compensation being provided.
A student athlete can obtain professional representation related to their NIL, but must provide their college or university with a copy of their representation contract within seven days of entering into it.
A student athlete's NIL contract cannot:
conflict with any provision in their college or university's rules or regulations;
be for the endorsement of products or services that are inconsistent with the values of a college or university, or that negatively impacts the college or university, including but not limited to:
gambling;
controlled substances;
tobacco or alcohol; or
adult entertainment services.
Permissible NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
A college or university can impose reasonable limitations on the dates and times that a student athlete may participate in endorsement, promotional, social media or other activities related to the license or use of the student-athlete's name, image, likeness or voice.
Further, a college or university can exercise its discretion to control the authorized use of its marks or logos or to determine a student-athlete's apparel, gear or other wearables during an intercollegiate athletics competition, including prohibiting a student athlete from wearing any item of clothing or gear with the name, logo or insignia of any entity during an intercollegiate athletics competition.
A college or university can fund an independent, third-party administrator to support education, monitoring, disclosures, and reporting concerning name, image, likeness, or voice activities by student-athletes.
NIL Agents/Advisors/Representatives
An agent or other representative must comply with the Federal Sports Agent Responsibility and Trust Act.

name: Kentucky
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Kentucky's NIL law allows student athletes to receive compensation for their name, image, and likeness, so long is it consistent with prevailing market rate of the authorized use of the athlete's name, image, or likeness.
Prohibitions and Required Conduct
Institutions and associations cannot prohibit or penalize student athletes for earning NIL compensation.
No person or entity can give or promise NIL compensation to recruit or induce an athlete to enroll at any Kentucky institution, or to recruit or induce a student athlete at a Kentucky institution to enroll at another institution (regardless of location).
Institutions, associations, or affiliated organization cannot compensate student athletes for use of NIL or negotiate any part of an NIL agreement on behalf of a prospective student athlete.
A student athlete's NIL contract cannot be for the endorsement or promotion of:
Sports betting;
Controlled substances,
Substances the student athlete's intercollegiate athletic association forbids the athlete from using;
Adult entertainment; or
Products or services that would be illegal for the student athlete to possess or receive.
Institutions may adopt policies governing NIL agreements of its student athletes. Any restrictions included in the policy must be in writing, reasonable, equitably enforced against all student athletes, and cannot place an undue burden on the student athlete's ability to earn compensation. Some examples of policies that are permissible are policies that:
Forbid or establish conditions for using the college or universities intellectual property; and
Prohibit a student athlete from entering into a NIL agreement for products or services that are reasonably considered to conflict with the mission of the college or university.
All prospective NIL contracts must be submitted to the college or university for approval. The college or university has three business days to review the proposed contract and provide the student athlete with notice of any conflicts. The student athlete can only enter into the contract after the conflicts are revolved. Any amendments to the contract must also be approved by the college or university.
Required NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
A college or university must provide its student athletes with a financial literacy and life skills education workshop for a minimum of five hours at the beginning of the athlete's first and third academic years, and must include information concerning:
Financial aid;
Debt management;
Saving and budgeting best practices;
Time management;
Available academic resources;
Skills necessary for success as a student athlete; and
Social media and brand management education.
The workshop cannot include any marketing, advertising, or referral for, or solicitation by, providers of financial, marketing, branding, or other NIL agreement products or services.
Amendments
Kentucky amended its NIL law in April 2024 to provide that the law's restrictions shall apply to NIL agreements only to the extent that an athletics association may regulate/restrict student athlete NIL agreements in a manner identical or substantially similar to those restrictions, including as currently or may be in the future modified by court order.

name: Louisiana
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Louisiana's NIL law allows student athletes to receive compensation for their name, image and likeness, so long as it is commensurate with the market value of the authorized use of the athlete's name, image, or likeness.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
The student athlete's NIL contract cannot endorse:
tobacco;
alcohol;
illegal substances or activities;
banned athletic substances; or
any form of gambling including sports wagering.
Similarly, it cannot use facilities, uniforms, registered trademarks, products protected by copyright, or official logos, marks, colors, or other indicia in connection with the use of the athlete's name, image, or likeness without the express permission of the college or university.
The student athlete must disclose their NIL contract to their college or university and the the NIL contract cannot conflict with a term of the athlete's athletic program's team contract.
A college or university may prohibit an athlete from using the athlete's name, image, or likeness for compensation if it would conflict with existing institutional sponsorship agreements or contracts, or institutional values.
Required NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
A college or university must conduct a financial literacy and life skills workshop for a minimum of five hours at the beginning of an intercollegiate athlete's first and third academic years. The workshop must, at a minimum, include information concerning:
financial aid;
debt management; and
a recommended budget for full and partial grant-in-aid athletes based on the cost of attendance for the current academic year;
time management skills necessary for success as an athlete; and
available academic resources.
The workshop cannot include any marketing, advertising, referral, or solicitation by providers of financial products or services.
NIL Agents/Advisors/Representatives
A student athlete can be represented by an agent or attorney. The agent must be registered with the state of Louisiana, and the attorney must be licensed to practice law.

name: Maine
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
The bill allows student athlete to earn compensation from the sale of the student athlete’s autograph.
Limitations on NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
This bill prohibits a college or university from preventing a student athlete from making certain contracts regarding or earning money from the use of the student athlete’s name, image or likeness or providing compensation for a prospective student athlete’s name, image or likeness.
The bill prohibits a group or organization with authority over intercollegiate athletics from preventing a college or university from participating in intercollegiate athletics in this state as a result of student athletes at the college or university earning compensation for the use of their name, image or likeness.

name: Maryland
summary:
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
The law precludes student-athletes from entering into NIL agreements that conflict with their athletic program contracts.
Any NIL agreement must be disclosed to a designated official at the school.
Athletes do not have a right to use school intellectual property in NIL activities without school permission.
Permissible NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
Schools may prohibit athletes from engaging in NIL activities during official and mandatory team activities. Athletes may hire agents and other representatives to assist with NIL activities.

name: Massachusetts
summary: N/A.

name: Michigan
Minnesota
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Student athletes are able to earn compensation for the use of her or his name, image, or likeness (NIL) through a multitude of different opportunities, such as endorsements, sponsorships, appearances, autographs, memorabilia, podcasts, camps, clinics, private lessons, crowdfunding.
Limitations on NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
A postsecondary institution must not uphold any rule, requirement, standard, or other limitation that prevents a student of that institution from fully participating in intercollegiate athletics and earning compensation as a result of the use of the student's name, image, or likeness rights or the student's athletic reputation.
The educational institution must not interfere with or prevent a student from fully participating in intercollegiate athletics for obtaining professional representation in relation to contracts or legal matters, including but not limited to representation provided by athlete agents, financial advisors, or legal representation provided by attorneys.

name: Mississippi
statusDetail: Enacted (4/16/2021); Effective (7/1/2021); First Amendment (8/28/2022); Second Amendment (4/18/2024); Third Amendment (04/23/2025).
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
The April 23, 2025 amendment allows institutions to directly compensate student athletes for use of their NIL, including through an athletics financial aid agreement. 
Student athletes can also profit from their NIL by participating in anything from sponsored social media posts, third-party endorsements, to making personal appearances. Institutions can facilitate, support, and negotiate opportunities for student athletes to potentially earn compensation for the use of their name, image, and likeness.
However, no person or entity may give or promise to share revenue or directly compensate for use of their NIL a student-athlete within the State of Mississippi for purposes of recruiting or inducing the student-athlete to enroll at another institution unless the student-athlete has given notice of an intent to transfer to a new institution.  Any entity that violates this restriction is liable to the institution where the student-athlete is enrolled or has signed an athletics financial aid agreement in an amount equal to three (3) times the amount given or offered to the transferring student-athlete.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
The law prohibits NIL activities with vice industries, like:
Alcohol;
Adult entertainment;
Cannabis;
Controlled substances;
Tobacco and tobacco products; and
Gambling and sports betting.
Students may not receive compensation from a third party if a provision of the agreement compensating the student conflicts with a provision of a contract, rule, regulation, standard, or other requirement of the postsecondary educational institution where the student-athlete is enrolled or intends to enroll.
Students may not use institutional IP without permission from the institution. If a student is granted use of institutional IP, the postsecondary educational institution may be compensated for this use.
Postsecondary education institutions are allowed to place "reasonable" limitations on the dates and time that student athletes can participate in endorsement-related activities.
Postsecondary education institutions may require a student athlete enrolled at their institution or who has announced an intention to enroll at their institution to disclose the agreement or its terms to a designated official of the institution.
Prohibition on Athletic Association Activity
Athletic associations or conferences may not:
Penalize an institution for engaging in conduct permitted by the amended statute;
Prevent an institution from or penalize an institution for engaging with a third party to facilitate NIL opportunities for its student-athletes; or
Penalize an institution because a related individual or entity engages in conduct that violates a contract, rule, regulation, standard, or other requirement that is in conflict with actions permitted under the amended statute.
Prohibition on Improper Recruiting Inducements
No person or entity, regardless of residence, can recruit or induce a student athlete to enroll at or or transfer to a specific institution within the State of Mississippi.
Institutional Responsibilities and Limitations
Postsecondary educational institutions' rights, including the ability to discuss with a student athlete the potential to earn NIL compensation if they attend the postsecondary educational institution, do not permit the institution to:
Receive compensation from the student athlete for facilitating an NIL opportunity;
Attempt to influence a student athlete's choice of professional representation relating to an NIL opportunity; or
Attempt in bad faith to reduce a student athlete's opportunities from competing third parties.
Institutions, as well as their officers, trustees, and employees, are not liable for any claims for damages relating to any permissible conduct under the amended statute.
Student Athletes Status as Employees
The amendment specifies that nothing there within shall be construed to qualify a student athlete as an employee of a postsecondary educational institution.

name: Missouri
summary:
Permissible NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
A postsecondary institution and any of its officers, directors, oy employees (including a coach, member of the coaching staff, or any individual associated with the institution’s athletics department) has the right to create, facilitate, negotiate, support, enable, or otherwise assist with student athlete NIL opportunities, provided any such individual does not receive compensation from the student athlete or third party for such facilitation, attempt to influence a student athlete’s choice of professional representation, or attempt to reduce a student athlete’s opportunities from competing third parties.
Institutional marketing associates may compensate student athletes for NIL use, including in promoting athletic events, the postsecondary institution itself, or the postsecondary institution’s athletics program.
Any student athlete can bring a civil action against third parties that violate Missouri’s NIL law or that interfere with a student athlete’s earning or attempting to earn NIL compensation.
A high school athlete in the state may earn NIL compensation only after signing an athletic letter of intent or other written agreement to enroll in a postsecondary institution in the state.  The high school athlete can only discuss earning NIL compensation before signing an athletic letter of intent only when having discussion about potential enrollment with a postsecondary institution in the state.
Limitations on NIL Activities 
Postsecondary institutions are prohibited from preventing student athletes from earning NIL compensation or obtaining professional or legal representation in relation to NIL activities.
NIL compensation cannot be conditioned on athletics performance but may be conditioned on the student athlete’s attendance at a particular postsecondary institution.
Student athletes cannot enter into sponsorship contracts requiring student athletes to advertise products during official team activities if such provisions conflict with the postsecondary institution’s contracts or licenses.
Student athletes cannot enter into NIL contracts that conflict with a postsecondary institution’s contracts, unless the institution consents.
Student athletes must disclose contract for NIL activities or professional representation to a postsecondary institution before execution.
Postsecondary institutions cannot compensate student athletes for NIL use, unless otherwise permitted by institutional policy and a collegiate athletics association that the institution is a member of.
Postsecondary institutions must develop procedures for granting student athletes or third parties licenses for use of the institutions’ or third parties’ unique identifiers when earning NIL compensation.
Postsecondary institutions or third parties can impose limitations on licenses where the use of unique identifiers is inconsistent with the institution’s or third party’s values or mission, adversely affects the institution’s or third party’s image, impacts the reputation or religious, moral, or ethical standards, violates the institution’s or third party’s code of conduct, or conflict with a provision of the institution’s or third party’s licenses or contracts.
Athletics associations and its member institutions cannot, among other things:
Prevent a postsecondary institution from establishing agreements with a third party entity to identify, facilitate, enable, or support student athlete NIL Activities;
Entertain a complaint, open an investigation, or take adverse action against a postsecondary institution for engaging in activity protected under Missouri’s NIL law;
Penalize a postsecondary institution because an institutional marketing associate compensate a student athlete for NIL use or if a third party violates the association’s rules regarding student athlete NIL.

name: Montana
summary:
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
A student athlete may not enter into a contract that provides compensation to the student athlete for the use of the student athlete’s name, image, or likeness if terms of the contract conflict with the student athlete’s team rules or with terms of a contract entered into between the student athlete’s postsecondary institution and a third party, except the team rules or a contract entered into between the postsecondary institution and a third party may not prevent a student athlete from earning compensation for the use of the student athlete’s name, image, or likeness when not engaged in official team activities.
Permissible NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
Unlike many other states, a postsecondary school may:
include provisions in scholarship agreements allowing the postsecondary school to use the athlete’s name, image, and likeness;
prohibit the use of an athlete’s name, image, and likeness on school property, at school functions, or in any advertising material distributed or placed on school property;
serve as an agent for the athlete to manage any contract using an athlete’s name, image, and likeness;
or do any combination of these subsections.
Following an amendment of the law in May 2025, institutions may now directly provide a prospective or current student athlete with compensation for use of their NIL.
Agreements Must Be in Writing
Per the May 2025 amendment, an agreement relating to a student athlete's NIL must be in writing.

name: Nebraska
summary:
Prohibitions & Required Conduct
Institutions cannot uphold any rules, requirements or limitations that prevent student athletes from participating in intercollegiate sports because of NIL compensation.
Athletics associations cannot penalize student athletes for earning NIL compensation or institutions at which student athletes earn NIL compensation.
Institutions cannot allow NIL compensation to affect the duration, amount, or eligibility for grants or scholarships (but may considered for need-based financial aid calculations).
NIL compensation must be for services actually performed and NIL contracts cannot extend beyond a student athlete's participation in an athletic program or involve the sale of exchange of awards of other items received for athletic participation.
Student athletes must disclose NIL contracts to their institutions.
Athletics associations cannot penalize student athletes or institutions for obtaining professional representation in relation to NIL contracts or legal matters.
Amendments
On April 18, 2022, Nebraska amended its NIL laws to:
Prohibit a student athlete from entering in contracts inconsistent with the educational mission of the school;
Not provide an automatic right for student athletes to use intellectual property that belongs to the school; and
Allow schools to offer educational training to student athletes to aid them in understanding their opportunities in areas such as:
Networking;
Brand building;
Finance; and
Compliance.
Nebraska Amended its NIL law again on April 16, 2024 to:
Provide that institutions cannot be prohibited from:
Creating, identifying, facilitating, enabling or supporting student athlete NIL activities;
Entering into agreements with a third-party entity to create, identify, facilitate, enable, or support student athlete NIL activities;
Provide that third-party entities cannot be prohibited from:
Communicating with student athletes to create, identify, facilitate, enable, or support student athlete NIL activities;
Compensating student athletes for use of NIL or promoting an athletics event the student athlete is participating in (provided the entity has an agreement to promote such event or the institution) or the institution the student athlete attends.
Prohibit institutions from compensate student athletes for use of their NIL unless authorized to by a athletics institution, court order, or settlement agreement.
Provide that nothing in the Nebraska NIL law shall be construed to qualify a student athlete as an employee of the institution.

name: Nevada
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
A student athlete may be compensated for the use of the name, image or likeness of the student athlete by certain organizations.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
Certain entities are prohibited from compensating a student athlete for the use of the name, image or likeness of the student athlete.

name: New Hampshire
summary: N/A.

name: New Jersey
New Mexico
summary:
Prohibited NIL Activities
The institution may not:
Limit the student athlete from full participation in athletics based on earning compensation for use of the student athlete’s NIL;
Prevent a student athlete from receiving compensation for use of their NIL when the athlete is not engaged in official, mandatory team activities;
Reduce, revoke, or refuse to renew a student athlete’s grant-in-aid or stipend, or otherwise alter their eligibility for the same, on the basis that the student athlete receives NIL compensation.
Third Party’s may not Offer a student athlete an NIL contract that requires the athlete to endorse the sponsor during official, mandatory team activities, without the approval of the institution..
Representation of Student Athletes
The Institution may not prevent a student athlete from fully participating in athletics on the basis of the athlete obtaining representation in relation to contracts or legal matters.
Amendments
New Mexico’s NIL law was amended in April 2023 to remove limitations regarding:
An institution’s ability to prohibit/discourage a student’s choice of footwear;
And institution’s ability to arrange third-party NIL compensation for a student, or to use such deals as recruiting inducements; and
An agent/firms ability to representative a student athlete attending an institution which the agent/firm represented within the last 4 years.

name: Ohio
summary:
Limitations on NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
The Ohio NIL law prevents institutions from prohibiting student athletes from entering NIL contracts. Institutions may prohibit student athletes from obtaining NIL endorsements from companies in certain industries, including:
controlled substances;
gambling;
adult entertainment; and
other similar industries.
The law requires a student athlete to disclose proposed NIL contracts to a designated official at the institution before the student athlete executes the contract.
Executive Order
On November 18, 2024, Ohio Governor Mike DeWine signed an Executive Order stating that “any postsecondary educational institution in the State of Ohio (that is covered by the [House] Settlement) may offer compensation or compensate an intercollegiate student-athlete for use of such student-athlete’s NIL.” The only restriction is that the institution may not use funds allocated by the State of Ohio to pay such compensation. The executive order recognizes that other states have taken action to authorize compensation paid by institutions to student-athletes, and it suggests that this Executive Order was necessary to “ensure a fair and level playing field” for Ohio’s postsecondary institutions.

name: Oklahoma
statusDetail: Enacted (5/28/21); Effective (1/1/2022); Amended (5/26/2023); Second Amendment (4/22/2024); Third Amendment (5/3/2025).
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Allows student athletes enrolled at institutions within the state to earn payment for use of their name, image, and likeness. Receiving such payment does not affect the student athlete’s eligibility for athletic grant-in-aid.
Institutions or a third party acting on behalf of the institution may provide professional representation and pay current and prospective student athletes for their NIL, if permitted by collegiate athletics association and institutional policy. However, institutions may not pay student athletes for their NIL using public funds allocated by the State of Oklahoma to the institution.
Institutions can adopt reasonable restrictions for student athletes so that NIL activities do not interfere with team activities, institutional operations, or the use of the institution's facilities. Institutions may also revoke or rescind a student athlete's grant-in-aid or other benefits received by the student athlete if they agree to receive impermissible NIL payment. Institutions may earn compensation for use of their marks or facilities in conjunction with a student athlete's NIL activities.
NIL Agents/Advisors/Representatives
Allows student athletes to be represented by any individual or entity relating to NIL activities. The May 2023 amendments removed the requirement that representatives be a registered agent or attorney admitted in the state.
All professional representation agreements must be in writing and disclosed to the institution.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
Student athletes must disclose any NIL contracts to their institution.
Student athletes also cannot:
Earn NIL compensation in exchange for participation in intercollegiate athletics or sports competition.
Earn NIL compensation while promoting products or services that conflict with an institution's policies or reflect adversely on the institution.
Prohibition on Athletic Association Activity
Collegiate athletics associations cannot:
Prevent institutions or a third party authorized to act on behalf of an institution from identifying, facilitating, enabling, or supporting NIL opportunities for student athletes.
Prohibit institutions from engaging with third-party entities to act on the institution's behalf to identify, facilitate, enable, or support student athlete NIL activities.
Entertain a complaint, open an investigation, or take adverse action against an institution or an employee or student athlete of an institution for engaging in activity protected under Oklahoma's Student Athlete Name, Image, and Likeness Rights Act or for involvement in student athlete NIL activities.
Intellectual Property Considerations
Student athletes are prohibited from using an institution's marks for the purpose of securing NIL compensation unless the contract is between the student athlete and the institution, or a third party authorized to act on behalf of the institution.
Student Athletes Status as Employees
The outlines that student athletes are not considered employees of an institution.

name: Oregon
summary:
Prohibitions and Required Conduct
Institutions, athletic associations, or conferences cannot:
Prohibit, prevent, or restrict student athletes from earning NIL compensation;
Penalize or retaliate against student athletes for earning NIL compensation;
Prohibit student athletes from participating in intercollegiate athletics for earning NIL compensation;
Impose eligibility requirements on scholarships/grants requiring student athletes from refraining from earning NIL compensation;
Prohibit student athletes from receiving food/drink/lodging/medical expense or insurance coverage as NIL compensation; or
Provide prospective or current student athletes with NIL compensation.
Student athletes cannot enter into NIL contracts where terms conflict with team rules or terms of a contract between an institutions and third party.
Student athletes must disclose NIL contracts to their institutions.
Student athletes cannot retain as an agent an individual who represented or was employed by an institution at any time in the preceding four years.
Other Provisions
Allows institutions to establish and enforce codes of conduct applicable to all students enrolled at the institution.
Amendments
A 2022 amendment to the law provides that a person making a profit by selling jerseys, trading cards, or video games that use student athletes' name, image, or likeness must pay royalty fees to student athletes.
The law was further amended in March 2024 to provide:
That athletics associations and conferences cannot prevent an institution or student athletes from participating in intercollegiate athletics, accept a complaint, open an investigation or take any adverse action against an institution or student athletes as a result of a violation, or alleged violation, of the rules of the athletics association or conference related to NIL compensation. Nor can an athletics association or conference authorized a member institution from taking such action.
That NIL compensation cannot be conditioned on athletic performance. But NIL compensation may be conditioned upon attendance at a particular institution.
That an athletics association or conference cannot prohibit an institution from identifying, facilitating, enabling, or supporting NIL opportunities.
That institutions (and their employees) cannot be held liable for damages to a student athletes NIL rights due to any decision that the institution/employee makes that is routinely taken in the course of intercollegiate sports or that is part of identifying, facilitating, enabling, or supporting NIL opportunities.

name: Pennsylvania
statusDetail:
Enacted (7/1/2021); Effective (7/1/2021).
First Amendment effective (11/3/2022); Second Amendment effective (7/17/2024).
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Pennsylvania's NIL law allows student athletes to earn compensation for the use of the name, image or likeness. Any person who uses a student athlete's NIL to produce a college team jersey, college team video game, or college team trading cards for profit must pay a royalty payment to the student athlete.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
The Pennsylvania NIL law includes provisions for restrictions on endorsements by student athletes in traditional vice industries, such as alcohol, gambling, and tobacco. Institutions can also prohibit NIL activities that conflict with institutional pre-existing sponsorship agreements. Institutions can also prohibit a student athlete's involvement in an NIL agreement when it conflicts with the institution's values, as defined by the institution.
Pursuant to the Act, student athlete may disclose NIL contracts to designated institutional officials prior to the execution of the contract. However, an institution may have policies that require, if the student athlete discloses, when the contract should be disclosed by, and what contents should be disclosed.
The Act does not give student athletes the right to use their college's name, trademark, or the like in furtherance of an NIL opportunity.
Professional Representation for Student Athlete NIL Activities
If a student athlete obtains professional representation in relation to the use of their NIL rights, the representing person must be either an athlete agent under Pennsylvania law or admitted to practice law in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. A contract by which a student athlete authorizes an athlete agent to negotiate or solicit compensation for the use of the student athlete's NIL must include a statement that the contract does not obligate the student athlete to use the agent for any services beyond professional representation in relation to the use of the student athlete's NIL.
Permissible NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
Educational institutions may arrange NIL deals for student athletes, but they are not required to do so.
Limitations on Educational Institutions and Intercollegiate Athletic Entities
Educational institutions and intercollegiate athletic associations cannot prevent or limit student athletes from earning NIL compensation for their name, image, or likeness. Educational institutions may also not revoke or reduce a student's athletic scholarship due to NIL compensation earned.
If an institution receives direct financial compensation from a third party arising from the third party's contract with the student athlete for the NIL, the institution is required to disclose in a timely manner the financial relationship between the institution and the third party to the student athlete; however, this does not apply to the use of the institution's IP.
An educational institution may not limit a student athlete's NIL rights through an athletics grant-in-aid or stipend scholarship. It may also not revoke or reduce a student athlete's grant-in-aid or stipend scholarship due to a student athlete earning NIL compensation.
An intercollegiate athletic entity may not: (1) prevent a student athlete from earning compensation through the use of their NIL rights; (2) prevent an educational institution from fully participating in intercollegiate athletics as a result of the student athlete's use of their NIL to seek compensation; or (3) entertain complaints, open investigations, or take any other adverse actions against an educational institution for activities permitted under Pennsylvania law or for directly compensating a student athlete for the use of their NIL.
A student athlete has a right to pursue a private civil action against an educational institution, intercollegiate athletic entity, or other person or entity that violates their rights under Pennsylvania's NIL law. Legal settlements made on or after June 30, 2021 may not permit a person or entity's noncompliance with the Pennsylvania NIL law.

name: South Carolina
summary:
While South Carolina’s NIL law still allows students to earn compensation for use of their NIL, South Carolina's May 2024 amendments changed large swathes of the law. As amended, South Carolina's NIL law provides as follows.
Permissible NIL Conduct
Institutions can directly, or through agreements with third parties, identify, create, solicit, facilitate, and otherwise enable NIL opportunities for currently enrolled student athletes.
Institutions can grant student athletes rights to use the institution's trademarks and facilities.
Limitations on NIL Conduct
Institutions may not receive compensation or fees directly from student athletes related to the facilitation of NIL.
No appropriated funds of an institution may be used to compensate student athletes for use of their NIL.
NIL compensation earned by a student athlete must be for NIL and independent from (i.e., not payment for) the student athlete's participation or performance, unless otherwise permitted by a college athletics association, an institutional policy, a court order, or a settlement agreement.
NIL contracts cannot extent beyond a student athlete's eligibility to participate in an intercollegiate athletics program.
Athletics associations (or other similar groups) cannot enforce rule/regulation that prohibits an institution from participating in intercollegiate sports for performing, participating in, or allowing activity authorized under the NIL law. This applies also to an institution's establishing agreements with third-party entities to act on the institution's behalf to identify, facilitate, enable, or support a student athlete's NIL.
An agency contract can provide for agent compensation, but cannot exceed 20% of the NIL contract.
Safe Harbors
Institutions are not liable for damages to a student athlete's ability to earn NIL compensation resulting from decisions/actions taken in the course of intercollegiate athletics. This does not apply to common law claims for fraud, fraudulent misrepresentation, or intentional misrepresentation.
Other Notable Amendments
Repealed Sections 7 and 8 of the NIL law regarding disclosures requiring separate acknowledgement and governing law.
Removed provisions regarding good academic standing requirements for student athletes.
Removed provision prohibiting NIL compensation in exchange for student athlete's attendance at a particular institution or contingent on a prospective student athlete's enrollment at a particular institution.
Removed provision prohibiting NIL activities from taking place during a student athlete's participation in academic, athletic, or team-mandated activities.
Removed provision prohibiting NIL compensation for the endorsement of tobacco, alcohol, illegal substances, or activities, banned athletic substances, or gambling.

name: Tennessee
statusDetail: Enacted; Amendment Effective (4/20/2022); Second Amendment Effective (5/1/2024); Third Amendment Effective (5/1/2025).
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Tennessee's NIL legislation allows student athletes to participate in NIL activities. The May 2025 amendment permits student athletes to receive broad NIL compensation, including for their enrollment at an institution and roster position with the institution's athletic program.
Neither a grant-in-aid for athletics awarded to a student athlete by an institution nor an institution or its "affiliated foundation's" (undefined) involvement in the support of a student athlete's NIL activities constitute NIL compensation. Additionally, receiving permissible NIL compensation does not affect the student athlete's grant-in-aid or athletic eligibility.
Limitations on Student-Athlete NIL Conduct
The legislation contains the traditional options for institutions to limit the use of institutional IP and a prohibition on NIL activities in connection with vice industries, like:
gambling;
alcohol;
tobacco; or
adult entertainment products.
Required NIL Activities
Tennessee colleges are required to conduct a financial literacy workshop for athletes new to the school. In addition, student athletes must now disclose any NIL agreement (and its terms) to the institution and file annual reports with the institution at which they are enrolled. The report must indicate, at a minimum, from whom the athlete is receiving compensation and the amount of compensation.
Permissible NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
An April 20, 2022, amendment removed restrictions on institutional activities. Subject to NCAA rules, institutional officials –– such as coaches –– can participate in NIL activities, such as maintaining involvement with an NIL collective. Additionally, the legislation permits institutions to set "reasonable time, place, and manner restrictions" on NIL activity to avoid it conflicting with team activities or institutional operations. Institutions may prohibit NIL activity where it conflicts with the values of the institution.
The May 2024 amendment removed additional restrictions on student athlete NIL compensation. In particular, the act no longer specifies that the compensation must be commensurate with "fair market value." Notably, the legislation removed the language in the statute that had prohibited student athletes from receiving compensation in exchange for athletic performance or attendance at an institution.
The May 2025 amendment permits third parties, including institutions and their "affiliated foundations," to compensate student athletes for their NIL, unless such action is prohibited by federal law, court order, or the institution's athletic association. Institutions may adjust a student athlete's need-based financial aid as a result of permissible NIL compensation received by the student athlete.
Limitations on NIL Activities (for Educational Institutions)
The May 2024 amendment prohibits institutions from adopting rules or requirements that "unduly restrict" student athletes from receiving NIL compensation. Such compensation does not effect a student's grant-in-aid or athletic eligibility, although, an institution may adjust need-based aid as a result of NIL compensation.
Protection for Educational Institutions
Institutions and their affiliated foundations "must not be held liable" for damages resulting from its "good faith decisions, actions, or involvement" in NIL activities.
NIL Agents/Advisors/Representatives
Student athletes can retain agents to secure NIL deals. All agents who represent student athletes must be licensed under Tennessee state law. The law also requires institutions to conduct a "financial literacy workshop" for student athletes.
The May 2024 amendment specifies that parents, siblings, grandparents, spouses, or legal guardians who represent the student athlete are not considered an "agent" for the purpose of this law. The same is true of institutions and their affiliated foundations who assist or facilitate NIL opportunities for student athletes.
Intercollegiate Athletic Associations
The May 2024 amendment specifically prohibits any intercollegiate athletic association from interfering with a student athlete's ability to earn compensation, seek representation, or perform due diligence in accordance with the Tennessee statute. The intercollegiate athletic association also may not interfere with the student athlete's eligibility unless the student athlete has committed a violation of the institution's rules.
The May 2025 amendment made several changes to the state's NIL laws:
Athletic associations must preserve all rights afforded to student athletes under applicable state and federal law and preserve all immunities and rights afforded to its member institutions under the same.
Athletic associations may not establish or adopt any rule or policy that violates state or federal antitrust law.
Athletic associations may not interfere with an institution's enjoyment of its current and future membership status in the athletic association.
Athletic associations may not impose unfair, anticompetitive, or unlawful conditions that directly or indirectly compel an institution or student athlete to participate under such conditions or risk violating state or federal law.
The athletic association must indemnify and hold harmless the state, its institution, and student athletes from any claims or damages arising from the state's noncompliance or failure under such applicable law.
Private institutions and an athletic association of which the institution is a member may reach a mutual agreement to opt out of these requirements with respect to the institution's student athletes. The opting-out private institution must provide notice to all its student athletes and all members of the athletic association of any mutual opt-out election within thirty (30) days of the mutual election or thirty (30) days of a student athlete's first enrollment at the institution, whichever is sooner. High School:
Permitted per Tennessee Secondary School Athletic Association rule amendment announced December 8, 2022. The May 2024 amendment expands the definition of athlete to include "a prospective student who has started or completed ninth grade and can, in the future, enroll in an institution and participate in an athletic program."

name: Texas
summary:
Limitations on NIL Conduct
An institution cannot:
Prohibit or prevent a student athlete from earning compensation for the use of the student athletes NIL when not engaged in official team activities;
Prohibit or prevent a student athlete from obtaining professional representation for matters relating to the use of the student athletes NIL; or
Solicit or provide a prospective student athlete with NIL related compensation.
An athletic association cannot penalize an institution for performing, participating in, or allowing an activity required or authorized by Texas’ NIL law.
A student athlete:
Must disclose proposed NIL contracts to the institution;
Cannot enter into an NIL contract if:
It conflicts with a provision of the student athlete’s team contract, institutional contract, or with a policy of the athletic department or provision of the institution’s honor code;
NIL compensation is provided (i) for athletic performance or for accepting an offer of admission to attend the institution; (ii) by the institution; (iii) for an act occurring while the student athlete is engaged in official team activities; or as an endorsement of alcohol, tobacco products, e-cigarettes, anabolic steroids, sports betting, casino gambling, firearms which the student athlete cannot legally purchase, or a sexually oriented business;
Cannot use the institution’s facility, uniforms, trademarks, copywritten products, or official logos in connection with an NIL contract unless the student obtains the institution’s express permission.
Activities of third-party entities which compensate student athletes for NIL use may not be construed as an act on behalf of an institution as long as the entity is a separate legal entity from the institution and the institution does not own or control the entity
Compensation
Texas’ NIL law excludes the following from the definition of compensation provided by an institution:
Recognition by the institution of a third-party entity which compensates students for NIL activities, or the entity’s donors, including the provision of priority status or other items of de minimis value.
An institution may not allow a student to use the institution’s facilities, uniforms, trademarks, copywritten products, or official logos in connection with an NIL contract unless the student athlete (and the individual or entity contracting for use of the student athlete’s NIL) comply with the institutions requirements and the institution is compensated at market rates.
Permissible Conduct
An institution or a third-party entity acting on its behalf may identify, create, facilitate, or otherwise assist with opportunities for student athletes to earn compensation for the use of the student athlete’s NIL, provided that the institution:
Does not act as an athlete agent for the student athlete;
Is not compensated by the student-athlete or third party for providing assistance;
Does not attempt to influence the student athletes choice of professional representation;
Does not attempt to diminish the student athletes opportunities from competing third parties.
501(c)(3) organization may compensate student athletes for use of their NIL.

name: Virginia
summary:
Permissible NIL Conduct
Virginia's NIL law allows student athletes to participate in NIL activities, and allows institutions to directly compensate student athletes for use of their name, image, and likeness.
Limitations on Student Athlete NIL Conduct
The law prohibits NIL activities with vice industries, like:
Alcohol;
Adult entertainment;
Cannabis or cannabis related products;
Controlled substances;
Performance enhancing drugs;
Drugs;
Tobacco and tobacco products;
Weapons; and
Gambling and casinos.
Student athletes must disclose proposed NIL agreements to institutions prior to execution. If a conflict exists between the student athletes' proposed NIL agreement and the institution's existing agreement, the institution can prohibit the student athlete from entering into such agreement.
Student athletes may not use institutional IP without permission from the institution.
Institutions may prohibit student athletes from earning NIL compensation while the student athlete is engaged in academic, official team, or athletic department activities.
Amendment (Passed 4/17/2024; Effective 7/1/2024).
On April 17, 2024, Virginia amended its collegiate NIL law to include the following:
Prohibition on Athletic Association Activity
Athletic associations or conferences may not prevent an institution from compensating a student-athlete for use of their NIL or otherwise prevent an institution (or an entity acting on its behalf) from identifying, creating, or otherwise assisting with NIL opportunities for student-athletes. Athletic associations or conferences cannot open an investigation into, or take adverse action against, an institution or any entity acting on its behalf for permitted NIL activity pursuant to the Virginia law. This includes penalizing an institution or student athlete for conduct by an individual or entity acting on behalf of the institution that violates the association's or conference's NIL rule.
Institutional Responsibilities and Limitations
Institutions may provide assets or other benefits as an incentive to individuals, companies, or other entities to provide money, benefits, opportunities, or services to an outside entity that supports NIL opportunities for the institution's student athletes.

Each institution must develop policies and procedures governing NIL compensation of student athletes. Those policies must not inhibit the student athlete from participating in activities unrelated to intercollegiate athletics, so long as such participation does not otherwise impact the student athlete's intercollegiate eligibility.

Institutions may not use "student fees" to compensate student-athletes for use of their NIL. These fees are defined as any fee assessed by the institution against a student that is used to support any of the institution's intercollegiate athletic programs.

Neither an institution, its supporting foundations, nor its employees are liable for damages to a student athlete's ability to earn NIL compensation resulting from decisions routinely taken in the course of intercollegiate athletics. If an institution, its supporting foundations, or an entity acting on its behalf is subjected to threatened or actual legal action for engaging in activities permitted by this law, they may bring a suit for damages, attorneys' fees, injunctive relief, and any other legal or equitable remedy.
Student Athletes Status as Employees; Right to Injunctive Relief
The amendments removed language that definitively stated the student athletes were not employees based on their participation in intercollegiate athletics. Instead, the law now states that the subsection in question does not qualify a student-athlete as an employee solely because that student-athlete engages in NIL opportunities.

A student athlete may bring an action for injunctive relief against an institution or athletic association/conference for violation of any provision of the this law.

name: Washington
summary:
Adds a new section to Chapter 42.52 (Ethics in Public Service) of Washington’s consolidated statutes clarifying that the chapter does not prohibit the use of public resources by an employee of a state institution of higher education to benefit any student athlete with regard to the advising, facilitation, acknowledgement, or education of NIL-related matters.
Provides, however, that public resources must adhere to the rules established by the national, nonprofit member organization responsible for oversight of college sports at state institutions of higher education.

name: West Virginia
summary:
Permitted NIL Activities (For Institutions)
Institutions may:
Enter into agreements to compensate student athletes for use of their NIL.
Share revenues generated by an intercollegiate athletic department with student athletes.
Establish terms and conditions on the receipt of NIL compensation, including prohibiting certain endorsements and prohibiting endorsement during official team activities.
Require that student athletes disclose third-party agreements.
Assist a student athlete in obtaining NIL opportunities.
Limitations on NIL Activity (For Institutions)
Institutions may not:
Use funds appropriated by the legislature to compensate a student for use of their NIL or engage in revenue sharing.
Punish a student athlete for engaging in NIL activities authorized by this law. This includes prohibitions on reducing or revoking an existing athletic scholarship on the basis of engagement in protected NIL activity.
Prohibited Endorsement Categories (For Student-Athletes)
Student athletes may not earn NIL compensation for promoting:
Alcohol, cannabis, controlled substances, performance enhancing drugs, drug paraphernalia, tobacco, or nicotine products; adult entertainment, casinos, gambling, nor sports betting.
Private Right of Action
The law provides that students who are aggrieved for engaging in activities authorized by this statute may bring a relief for injunctive relief. Conversely, any institution that is subjected to threatened or actual adverse action  perpetrated by an athletic association, conference, or other organization having authority over collegiate athletics  for engaging in activities authorized by this act may sue to recover (a) actual damages, (b) attorney fees, (c) injunctive relief, and (d) any other remedy in law or equity.
Student-Athletes Not Employees
The Act explicitly states that it should not be construed to qualify student athletes as employees of an institution solely because they earn NIL compensation from the institution or engage in permitted revenue sharing under this law.
